dc:dc.dc:title: Sunshine, Feiner, and Ginsberg Families Composite
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 94.

On envelope: ''#78 Sunshine, Feiner and Ginsberg Families Immigrants''. On note inside envelope: ''#78 Immigrants: Mr. and Mrs. Sunshine Donor: Mrs. Albert Brennan Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Feiner Donor: Mr. Louis Cook Mr. and MRs. Jacob Sarnoff Ginsberg. He made 6 crossings to Russia and died in Brest-Letovsk, 1914 Donor: Mrs. Ira Beck''.

Three formal poses of the heads of the Sunshine, Feiner, and Ginsberg families: Mr. and Mrs. Sunshine (left, standing), Mr.and Mrs. Jacob Feiner (center, seated and wearing hats), Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Sarnoff Ginsberg (right, she is standing, he is seated). Composite was made sometime in the 1970s, but the original images date to the early 20th century.
Donated by Mrs. Albert Brenman, Mr. Louis cook and Mrs. Ira Beck.

dc:dc.dc:title: Annie Miller and Daughters in Front of Orlinsky Cash Grocery and Meat Market
Photograph caption, p. 41, Jewish Denver, 1859-1940. __Annie Orlinsky Miller and daughters Sara and Celia appear in front of Orlinsky's Grocery c. 1910.
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 4 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 41.

Handwritten on envelope: "#309 Millers in front of Orlinsky's Grocery." Handwritten on front of photograph: "Annie Miller, Sarah & Celia." Handwritten on back of photograph: "#309 Annie Miller & daughters Sarah and Celia in front of Orlinsky Cash Grocery & Meat Market, 8th Ave & Mariposa."

The Miller Family stands in front of the Orlinsky Cash Grocery and Meat Market. Annie Orlinsky Miller stands behind her daughters, Sarah and Celia. The store was located on 8th Avenue and Mariposa Street in Denver, Colorado. Annie Miller helped support her family by operating her own store.
Copy donated by Milton Morris, a friend of the Orlinsky family.

dc:dc.dc:title: Physicians of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#460 J.C.R.S. Staff''. On back of photograph: ''Dr. Schwatt center Dr. Arthur Rest extreme right J.C.R.S. Drs. 1938 Perhaps Dr. Rest can tell you who Drs. are''.

Group portrait of physicians of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Dr. Herman Schwatt is pictured in the center and Dr. Arthur Rest is on the far right. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).
ph460

dc:dc.dc:title: Exterior View of Yad Achass (Rumanian Shul)
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Courtesy of Charles McNamara.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 66.
Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Rumansche Shul, Photograph by Charles McNamara, 1979.''

Many small synagogues, or shuls, were built in Denver, Colorado's west-side with the East European immigrant Jewish community, including Yad Achass, more commonly known as the Rumansche (Romanian) shul. It was orgainized in 1903, and its second home, pictured here, was at the corner of King Street and Conejos Place.
The photograph donated by the photographer, Charles McNamara.
ph38

dc:dc.dc:title: Schachet Mercantile Company
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#217 Schuachet Mercantile Co [sic]''. On back of photograph: ''#217 Schuchet [sic] Mercantile Company 1978 W. Colfax near Stor Briad Donor Charles McNamera West Side 2u.''

Exterior view of the Schachet Mercantile Company on West Colfax Avenue in Denver, Colorado. The building was originally built as a saloon in 1896, rented by Eli Schachet and his sons in 1918 and served as the headquarters for their meat and fish store until it closed in 1981. Schachet came to Denver for his health and served the Jewish West Colfax neighborhood for many years as a ''schochet'' (ritual slaughterer for kosher meat). With his sons, he expanded his business to include smoked fish delicacies such as lox and sable. A close friend of Berel Manischewitz, the founder of the B. Manischewitz Company, a specialty food company that specialized in matzo, or unleavened bread, Schachet became the exclusive distributor for the newly formed Manischewitz Company products in Colorado and other western states. Bugsy Siegel ate at the delicatessen that was part of the Mercantile Co. when he was in Denver. The building currently houses Brooklyn's Sports Bar, and the production of smoked fish is now carried on in Edgewater, Colorado under the name Arctic Pacific Fisheries.
Donated by Charles McNamara.

dc:dc.dc:title: Channah Milstein Wearing a Kerchief
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 4 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 75.
Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Channah Milstein, grandmother? of Phil Milstein, member 'Glazierlach' clan of west-side Denver, Cotopaxi colonist, donor Mrs. Sylvan Moses.''

Head and shoulders portrait of Mrs. Channah Milstein wearing a traditional kerchief or tichel headcovering. She was a member of the Jewish "Glazierlach" clan and a Cotopaxi colonist before moving to Denver's west side Orthodox Jewish Community. Channah Milstein was known for her personal commitment to charity in Denver's west-side East European immigrant Jewish community as she urged residents to contribute to her collections of food, clothing, and money for the needy.
Donated by Mrs. Sylvan Moses who retained the original.

dc:dc.dc:title: Rabbi Elias Hillkowitz
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 67.
On back of photograph: ''Rabbi Elias Hillkowitz.''

Rabbi Elias Hillkowitz was considered the dean of Denver's early west-side Orthodox Jewish rabbis. He was an early supporter of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS), where his son, Dr. Philip Hillkowitz, served as president from 1904 to 1948. Rabbi Hillkowitz suggested the JCRS motto from the Talmud: ''He who saves one life saves the world.''
Photograph from JCRS publication, The Sanatorium.

dc:dc.dc:title: Shul Baer Milstein Sits with a Long Pipe
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5.5 x 4 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 65.
Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Shul Baer Milstein, 1880s.''

Shul Baer Milstein, wearing a yarmulka and smoking a long pipe, sits at a table with an open Talmud in front of him. A tapestry hangs on the wall behind his chair. Milstein, who immigrated from Russia, was an early leader in Denver's west side Orthodox Jewish community and in Congregation Zera Abraham. He was also a patriarch of the Cotopaxi Colony, an agricultural community located in Cotopaxi, Colorado that failed in 1884. He was a peddler and later opened his own kosher butcher shop.
Donated by Freda Toltz

dc:dc.dc:title: Art Class at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#462 JCRS Patient Activities''. On back of photograph: ''#462 JCRS Art Class - 1942''.

An art class that is part of the rehabilitation program of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) meets for a session. Male patients sit on folding chairs in a half circle around a male model wearing a robe, pajamas, slippers and hat. Max Lazarus, a German-Jewish artist, is pictured second from the left. Twenty-three charcoal drawings hang on the walls. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

dc:dc.dc:title: Exterior of the first National Jewish Hospital building (The Frances Jacobs Hospital)
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America, Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 76.
On back of photograph: ''#1116 First NJH Building, 1899 pg. 30''. On envelope: ''#1116 National Jewish Hospital - Misc. Historic Photos Patient Days of Care By State, 1949''.

Exterior shot features a sign over the top front porch, which reads, "The Frances Jacobs Hospital". The name was changed to National Jewish Hospital in 1899. Two men (unidentified) stand in front of the building. In 1907, the name of the hospital changed to the National Asthma Center. It later became the Children's Asthma Research Institute and Hospital, National Jewish Hospital/National Asthma Center (1978), and National Jewish Center for Immunology and Respiratory Medicine (1985).
Donated by the National Jewish Hospital.

dc:dc.dc:title: Ed Grimes
Title on envelope: __Formal Portrait of Ed Grimes
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5.5 x 4 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten on back of photograph: ''E. Grimes.''

Ed Grimes in a formal portrait taken for the Independent Order of B'nai B'rith Lodge #171 in Denver, Colorado. Ed Grimes was a colonist at Cotopaxi, Colorado and walked to Denver from Cotopaxi in 1883, a distance of about 94 miles. He later served as Congregation Zera Abraham's first president and was also active in B'nai B'rith Lodge #171.
Donated by the Independent Order of B'nai B'rith Lodge #171 (Denver, Colo.)

dc:dc.dc:title: Members of the Stein Family Pose with the Company Vehicle
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on envelope: "# 386 Stein family of Pueblo, 1900-1960 info inside." Photocopy of handwritten note inside original envelope: "Taken in Pueblo, Colorado between 1913 and 1914. Max Stein arrived in Pueblo in 1898 (he is the man on the right) after serving as a mounted policeman, he began peddling fruit and vegetables from a wagon. About 1910 he opened a retail grocery store at 1156 4th St., Pueblo. The business is still in the same location but has expanded to become a wholesale food company. Marvin Stein, the present owner, is a third-generation Stein." Handwritten note on front of photocopy: "In car, Max Stein, Billy Sisson, L to R, John Myers, Albert Stein."

Max Stein and Billy Sisson are seated inside a Willys-Overland automobile, which is decorated for a parade. There is a large sign on the roof of the vehicle which states "Stein's Grocery and Market Quality Without Extravagance Agents Battle Creek Sanitarium Health Foods." John Myers and Albert Stein are standing behind the front of the vehicle, from left to right.

dc:dc.dc:title: Clara Goldsmith Stands in Formal Pose
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 15.
Handwritten on envelope: ''Goldsmith, Clara (Weil) (sic), born Denver 1860.''

Clara Goldsmith Weil stands behind a fence prop for a formal portrait. Clara, born in 1860, was the first female Jewish baby born in Denver. Clara's parents, Clara and Henry Goldsmith, had migrated by covered wagon from Leavenworth, Kansas. The elder Clara died in childbirth and her daugher was named after her mother. Clara Goldsmith Weil was raised by her aunt and uncle Rosa and Abraham Goldsmith. The elder Clara Goldsmith's death was the impetus behind the organization of Denver's first Jewish burial society.
Donated by Dorothy Shipman.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#136 Fannie Lorber at Sheltering Home.'' On back of photograph: ''#136 Fannie Lorber Breaking Ground at the Sheltering Home 1937?''

Mrs. Fannie E. Lorber was one of the founders of the Denver Sheltering Home, which opened in 1908. She is shoveling dirt for a groundbreaking of the Lorber Building, with many men and women looking on. The Sheltering Home began as a home for the children of tubercular patients who came to the sanitoriums in Denver, Colo.

dc:dc.dc:title: Dr. Charles Spivak at His Desk With Dictaphone
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
On back of photograph: ''Dr. Charles Spivak #1124.''

Dr. Charles Spivak sits at his desk and speaks into a dictaphone. Dr. Spivak was a founder of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

Handwritten on envelope: ''#180 JCRS Group of pictures''. On back of photograph: ''#180 JCRS Texas Building now the cancer hospital''.

The Texas Pavilion for Women Building on the campus of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) opened in 1927. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver. As of 2009, the Texas Pavilion was being used as part of the Rocky Mountain College of Art and Design.
Donated by Marjorie Hornbein.

dc:dc.dc:title: Ray David
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, Black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 74.

Ray S. David stands in an outdoor setting in a suit and hat. In 1915, Mrs. Ray S. David was hired as superintendent of the Denver's Jewish Aid Society to supervise relief activities. She was nicknamed ''Little Mother to the Poor'' for her settlement work with East European Jewish immigrants. Ray David was a member of the Woman's Club of Denver, Denver Board of Charities and Corrections as well as the State Board of Pardons, and campaigned for women's suffrage.
Copy donated by Ray David's granddaughter Bobbie Meyer.

The five Shwayder brothers stand on a board that is balanced on a Samsonite suitcase to demonstrate the strength of the suitcase. Jesse Shwayder is pictured second from the right. dc:dc.dc:title: Irving and Arthur Hayutin Seated in a Goat Cart
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 4.5 x 6 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 100.
On envelope: ''Hayutin Children, 1924, Irving age 6, Arthur age 3.''

Irving (age 6) and Arthur (age 3) Hayutin sit together in a small cart drawn by a goat in front of their childhood home on Denver's west side. Irving wears a cap and Arthur wears a hat and coat. The cart is inscribed with the words, ''Denver 1924.'' Irving and Arthur, who both became attorneys, were the sons of Morris and Anna Ginsberg Hayutin and the brothers of Peryle Hayutin Beck.
Donated by Peryle Hayutin Beck in December 1976.

dc:dc.dc:title: Interior of Isaacs' Hardware Store in Leadville
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Newspaper article with the photo titled ''Leadville Woman has Oldest Range in Rocky Mountains'' (undated) states that two individuals, Eva Zelezniker and Joe Matekal, owned the two oldest working Monarch coal ranges in the Rocky Mountain region. Monarch gave her a new electric range and him an electric griddle. The coal ranges had been purchased in Hyman Isaacs store in the early 1900s and had been advertised by Isaacs in the Herald Democrat as the ''Stay Satisfactory'' range.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 117.

Handwritten on envelope: "167 Isaac's Hardware Store, Leadville, c 1909." Handwritten on back of photograph: "#167, Hyman Isaac's Hardware Store in Leadville btn 4th and 5th (420?) Harrison Ave. c. 1909, See Leadville file for description."
Interior view of Hyman Isaacs' Hardware Store in Leadville, Colorado. There is an unidentified man in the center of the photograph who is leaning against a counter.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#586 Beth Israel Hospital and Geriatric Center Guldman and Dupler Bldgs.''. On back of photograph: ''#586 Beth Israel Hospital and Geriatric Center Guldman and Dupler Bldgs''.

Exterior view of Beth Israel Hospital and Geriatric Center in Denver, Colorado. Beth Israel was founded in 1905 and was located on the west side of Denver at 16th Avenue and Lowell Boulevard. Pictured are the Guldman and Dupler Buildings.

dc:dc.dc:title: Home of Abraham Jacobs
Title from back of photograph: __Home of A Jacobs, 16th Welton St.
dc:dc.dc:format: 2 item (photograph), 6 x 4 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 11.

On front of photograph, printed on the card portion: ''A.E. Rinehart, Denver, Colo.'' On back of photograph: ''A.E. Rinehart'' and: ''Duplicates can be had at any time'' in gold colored script, with gold colored logo: ''Larimer Street, 413 Denver, Col.'' Handwritten on the back: ''Home of A Jacobs, 16th Welton St., Before Masonic Temple was built there.''

View of the exterior of the Abraham and Frances Wisebart Jacobs home at 16th Ave. and Welton St., Denver, Colo. View shows surrounding fence, with neighborhood homes, trees and streetcar lines visible in the background. Abraham Jacobs was a clothing merchant, his wife Frances was impetus behind founding of National Jewish Hospital.

Original owners were Abraham and Frances Wisebart Jacobs. The photograph was given to Jean Morris, their great-niece, who donated it to the Beck Archives in 1977. Related material may be found in the Frances Wisebart Jacobs Clothing and Other Material, B148.

dc:dc.dc:title: Central Electric
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 11 x 14 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Aerial view of the Central Electric Company surrounded by other industrial buildings beside the Valley Highway [Interstate 25]. Sam Beck founded the Central Electric Supply Co. and was elected chairman. Ira M. Beck succeeded his father as the president of the company in 1969.

dc:dc.dc:title: Bronze Statue of Frances Wisebart Jacobs
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 75.
On envelope: ''#818 Frances Jacobs Statue''.

Bronze statue is an artist's rendering of Frances Wisebart Jacobs holding her bag of soaps and medicines. The plaque affixed to the base of statue explains Jacob's ties with National Jewish Hospital, which was founded in her memory. The statue is located in the National Jewish Center, Denver, Colo.
Photograph was donated by National Jewish Hospital.
